qas.question: What was the Top Hoodlum Program a response to?
What did the Top Hoodlum Program gather information on?
After the RICO Act took effect what did the FBI start investigating?
What groups did Hoover deny the existence of?
Is the RICO Act still used today?

answers.text: The RICO Act is still used

qas.question: How did the FBI respond to organized crime before 1953?
What did the FBI do before the RICO Act took effect?
What did Hoover confirm the existence of?
Who was the head of a crime family the CIA targeted?
What act is not longer in use?

context: In response to <a0_0>organized crime<a0_0/>, on August 25, 1953, the FBI <b5_0>created the Top Hoodlum Program<b5_0/>. The national office directed field offices to gather information on <a1_0>mobsters<a1_0/> in their territories and to report it regularly to Washington for a centralized collection of intelligence on racketeers. After the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO Act, took effect, the FBI <b6_0>began investigating<b6_0/> the <a2_0>former Prohibition-organized groups<a2_0/>, which had become fronts for crime in major cities and small towns. All of the FBI work was done undercover and from within these organizations, using the provisions provided in the RICO Act. Gradually the agency dismantled many of the groups. Although Hoover initially denied the existence of a <a3_0><b7_0>National Crime Syndicate<b7_0/><a3_0/> in the United States, the Bureau later conducted operations against known organized crime syndicates and families, including those headed by <b8_0>Sam Giancana<b8_0/> and John Gotti. <a4_0>The <b9_0>RICO Act<b9_0/> is still used<a4_0/> today for all organized crime and any individuals who might fall under the Act.
